body:
See below an example of this behavior:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12629429/133665479-5004519e-be24-4e8b-bc15-a4606523c39a.png)

This behaviour is intentional. You can prevent this by modifying the module format strings (`starship print-config` might be helpful if you wish to replace all the module format strings). For example, you could replace `"via [$symbol($version )]($style)"` with `'(via [$symbol$version ]($style))'` to ensure it's only shown when `$version` has a value and the relevant binaries are installed.

A preset with format string might be a good addition for the preset page, though.
Thanks! That's perfect. I think some extra documentation as mentioned would be useful.

issue.title: docs(3070): add some precision on how to hide non installed plugins

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
#### Description

Update configuration documentation to indicate how to hide plugin which are not installed. 

#### Motivation and Context

Closes #3070

I'm not sure if this is the best way to address this issue, I tried to find an "update all configuration" method with a regex matching most of the plugin but there is maybe a better way.

#### How Has This Been Tested?

Only documentation have been changed. 

#### Checklist:

- [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [ ] I have updated the tests accordingly

body:
Hello, I submitted an PR to (try to) improve this documentation part. and added a regex example on how to do a global find and replace.

I'm not sure if this is the best way to address this issue but hope you'll find this useful !

issue.title: Starship will show icons even for languages it fails to find a version of

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
#### Current Behavior
Starship will show icons even for languages it fails to find a version of. For example, I don't have a global Lua interpreter installed, I create a `.lua` file in the current directory and I get a Lua module rendered without a version showing, which is rather confusing...

#### Expected Behavior
I expected it to either not render the module or have some indication that it didn't find any version (Shouldn't really be a big warning, it is common to encounter files for some language without actually having the language installed), just the icon is confusing...

#### Additional context/Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24731903/142411458-00603c93-f32f-4118-9559-f4ae42ee3fe4.png)

#### Possible Solution
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 

#### Environment
- Starship version: 1.0.0
- powershell version: 7.2.0
- Operating system: Windows 10.0.19043
- Terminal emulator: Windows Terminal v1.11.2921.0
- Git Commit Hash: dfbf861f
- Branch/Tag: v1.0.0
- Rust Version: rustc 1.56.1 (59eed8a2a 2021-11-01)
- Rust channel: stable-x86_64-pc-windows-msvc (default) release
- Build Time: 2021-11-09 21:38:43 +00:00
#### Relevant Shell Configuration

```bash
Import-Module PSFzf
Import-Module posh-git
Import-Module DockerCompletion

$env:PAGER='less'
$env:LESS='-R'
$env:LESSCHARSET='utf-8'

Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler -Key UpArrow -Function HistorySearchBackward
Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler -Key DownArrow -Function HistorySearchForward
Set-PSReadLineOption -HistorySearchCursorMovesToEnd
Set-PSReadLineOption -ExtraPromptLineCount 2
Set-PSReadLineOption -ContinuationPrompt "`e[1;33m‚ùØ`e[0m "

Set-PsFzfOption -PSReadlineChordReverseHistory 'Ctrl+r'

Invoke-Expression (&starship init powershell)

New-Alias npp 'C:\Program Files\Notepad++\notepad++.exe'
New-Alias 7z 'C:\Program Files\7-Zip\7z.exe'
```

#### Starship Configuration

```toml
[directory]
truncation_symbol = "‚Ä¶/"

[battery]
full_symbol = "‚Ä¢ "
charging_symbol = "‚á° "
discharging_symbol = "‚á£ "
unknown_symbol = "‚ùì "
empty_symbol = "‚ùó "

[erlang]
symbol = "erl "

[nodejs]
symbol = "[‚¨¢](bold green) "

[pulumi]
symbol = "pulumi "

```

body:
The title and OP of this ticket talks about Starship behavior.

When @davidkna added the documentation label, they talked about adding a configuration preset.

#3248 discusses Starship behavior.

Am I right to assume then that this ticket is about adding a preset for hiding module format on missing toolsets - despite the ticket title and post being about something different?

issue.title: feat(preset): Add No Empty Icons preset

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
When toolset files are identified by the Starship module, the default format displays the toolset icon, and additional information.

When the toolset executables are not available, the additional information (like version number) is missing. Only the toolset icon is displayed.

The No Empty Icons preset changes the format configuration to not show the toolset icons if the variables are empty - presumably because the toolset is not installed or found.

Closes #3070
Related #3248

body:
I simply wasn't aware it was possible at first - I've since adapted my own config with this workaround. A preset and/or documentation would certainly help other users in the future though.

That being said, I personally believe the UX would be better if you had to _opt in_ to the current behavior, for two reasons:
1. I don't think this behavior is intuitive. Why would a user care about something they don't have installed? If they really do care about it, I think it's reasonable to then explicitly enable said module.
2. It makes the user's config extremely verbose. For example, here's [my config](https://github.com/aw1cks-dotfiles/dotfiles/blob/676d4c6d1238fc88d40e462a920a871b9a251c53/dot_config/starship.toml). I have to reconfigure many modules that I don't use (sure, I could disable them instead of overriding the format string, but that still seems rather unnecessary). The user also has to update their config every time a new module gets added - not ideal.
